title.narrative: Legal and governance framework for sand concessions

description.narrative: Vietnam Marine sand concession – Legal & governance frameworkThis report aims to trigger Vietnam’s interests in implementing an encouraging marine (offshore) sand sourcing policy by streamlining its current Legal & Governance (“L&G”) framework to better facilitate the granting of marine sand concessions and permits to market players in view of international practice. It also aims to provide relevant market players with an overview of Vietnam’s regulatory framework for pursuing offshore sand sourcing activities in Vietnam.According to Vietnam’s maritime strategy, Vietnam aims to turn into a strong maritime nation by 2030, whereby 65-70% of Vietnam’s GDP should come from the 28 coastal provinces and cities of Vietnam. This means that urbanization and industrialization in these coastal provinces are expected to growth significantly in the coming years. These urbanization and industrialization growth will lead to a growing demand of elementary (construction) materials such as sand. At the same time, traditional onshore sand reserve locations/resources in Vietnam such as riverbeds are becoming more and more exhaustive, and negative social and environmental impacts of onshore sand sourcing at these traditional sand sourcing locations are becoming more sensible. A call for a responsible sand sourcing policy in Vietnam is therefore becoming more stringent and urgent. As such, this report would aim to support the sustainable development goals of the United Nations, specifically SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure) and SDG 13 (Climate action).The Netherlands has extensive experience in marine sand sourcing in the North Sea, using environmentally friendly sand extraction methods to supply the growing sand demands while at the same time mitigating negative environmental and social impacts. Vietnam could explore and develop further its marine sand sourcing potential as one of the key solutions for a responsible sand sourcing policy, especially in facilitating large sand demands for land reclamation – port/maritime infrastructure – and coast protection/beach replenishment – projects. In order to further develop this marine sand sourcing potential in Vietnam, it would be essential that Vietnam would develop a robust but practically applicable L&G framework for marine sand sourcing.The report consists of 8 chapters, the first 2 chapters provide an overview of the current Vietnam respectively international sand sourcing practices. Chapter 3 provides an overview of the Dutch respectively UK marine/offshore sand sourcing L&G framework. Chapters 4, 5, 6 and 7 provide the current Vietnamese L&G framework for marine sand sourcing. In the last chapter, a two track approach – consisting of a pilot test case offshore sand extraction permitting in combination with a more structural L&G amending trajectory – is proposed for Vietnam to overcome its L&G framework challenges. With this two track approach proposal, we aim to trigger Vietnam’s interest in further streamlining its L&G framework to facilitate an encouraging policy of marine sand sourcing in Vietnam.
